required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 14, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Migrant Workers' Responses to the COVID-19 Pandemic
clinical_study.official_title: Responses of International Migrant Workers to Large-Scale Dormitory Outbreaks of COVID-19: A Population Survey

brief_summary.textblock: In this study, we seek to document (i) migrant worker's trust in their host country's government, (ii) migrant worker's exposure to unreliable COVID-19 information (i.e., rumours) and (iii) the situational and demographic variables that predict degree of exposure to unreliable information during the coronavirus-19 pandemic.

detailed_description.textblock:
Trust in institutions is vital for effective pandemic response as it lowers fear and increases compliance. Access to reliable information is a key factor in fostering trust. However, migrant workers are a disadvantaged population that traditionally lack access to reliable sources of information.
In this study, we seek to document (i) migrant worker's trust in their host country's government, (ii) migrant worker's exposure to unreliable COVID-19 information (i.e., rumours), (iii) the situational and demographic variables that predict degree of exposure to unreliable information.
Data was taken from the COVID-19 Migrant Health Study, a cross-sectional study of male migrants employed in manual labor jobs within Singapore.

primary_outcome.description: Participants were asked how confident they were that the government could control the nationwide spread of COVID-19
Participants were asked how fearful they were about their health during the COVID-19 situation
Participants were asked how fearful they were about their job during the COVID-19 situation
Participants who had not been infected with COVID-19 were asked how likely it was that they would be infected with COVID-19

We investigated participants' familiarity with five rumors that had been widely spread during the COVID-19 pandemic: (1) drinking water frequently will help prevent infection (COVID-19 prevention); (2) eating garlic can help prevent infection (COVID-19 prevention); (3) the outbreak arose from people eating bat soup (COVID-19 origins); (4) the virus was created in a US lab to affect China's economy (COVID-19 origins); and (5) the virus was created in a Chinese lab as a bioweapon (COVID-19 origins).

study_pop.textblock: The study population consist of male migrant workers employed in manual labor jobs within Singapore

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- At least 21 years old
- Holds a government work permit identifying their employment status
Exclusion Criteria:
- NIL

patient_data.ipd_description: Due to stipulations by the Institutional Review Board, data cannot be shared.
